thread.title: NASA to make announcement about Earth-like planets today
thread.title_full: NASA to make announcement about Earth-like planets today

author: Richard Tribou
title: NASA to make announcement about Earth-like planets today
text:
NASA to make announcement about Earth-like planets today A look at NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope 
NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope, which launched Aug. 25, 2003, began an extended mission - the "Beyond" phase - on Oct. 1, 2016. 
NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope, which launched Aug. 25, 2003, began an extended mission - the "Beyond" phase - on Oct. 1, 2016. Richard Tribou will make an announcement about new exoplanet findings today at 1 p.m.
The details of the findings appear in the science journal Nature, and are embargoed until 1 p.m., but regard Earth-like planets in a neighboring star system. 
Involved in today’s briefing are Thomas Zurbuchen, associate administrator of the Science Mission Directorate at NASA Headquarters in Washington; Michael Gillon, astronomer at the University of Liege in Belgium; Sean Carey, manager of NASA's Spitzer Science Center at Caltech/IPAC, Pasadena, California; Nikole Lewis, astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore; and Sara Seager, professor of planetary science and physics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge. 
The Spitzer Space Telescope has been involved along with Hubble Space Telescope in the search for exoplanets, planets not in our solar system. Researchers are looking for exoplanets in the habitable zone, meaning those that might have water, the basis for life on Earth. 
One of the panelists, Gillon, has previously published works on exoplanets using the Spitzer Space Telescope, having found three exoplanets in a system just shy of 40 light years away . 
Following the 1 p.m. announcement, a Reddit AMA (Ask Me Anything) about exoplanets will be held at 3 p.m. 
You can view the announcement at 1 p.m. on NASA TV at http://www.nasa.gov/nasatv Caption Rocket launches set to return to NASA property 
This weekend's scheduled SpaceX rocket launch will be the first on NASA property in five years.

This weekend's scheduled SpaceX rocket launch will be the first on NASA property in five years. 
This weekend's scheduled SpaceX rocket launch will be the first on NASA property in five years. Caption SpaceX will attempt three commercial spaceflight firsts in 2017 
The debut of a new rocket, the first reflight of a previously used first-stage rocket booster, and the first test flight of an unmanned test capsule are among the 70 missions on the company's launch manifest. 
The debut of a new rocket, the first reflight of a previously used first-stage rocket booster, and the first test flight of an unmanned test capsule are among the 70 missions on the company's launch manifest. Caption 3 must-see activities at 'Astronaut' exhibit at Orlando Science Center 
From the centifuge capsule to the space toilet, the 'Astronaut' exhibit at the Orlando Science Center tests visitors to see if they have the right stuff to go into outer space. 
From the centifuge capsule to the space toilet, the 'Astronaut' exhibit at the Orlando Science Center tests visitors to see if they have the right stuff to go into outer space. Caption SpaceX to launch from launch pad 39A 
A new SpaceX rocket launch will take place on launch pad 39A and will be a historic first. 
A new SpaceX rocket launch will take place on launch pad 39A and will be a historic first. Caption NASA's Michoud Assembly Facility Impacted by Tornado 
A tornado impacted NASA’s Michoud Assembly Facility in New Orleans on Feb. 7. Only minor injuries have been reported and NASA employees and other tenants are being accounted for.
